panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

seriesOverrides.alias: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: git Service Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_5m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_1h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_30m{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_service_apdex:ratio_6h{env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.content:
### Description

Measures aggregated HTTP request traffic through the HAProxy.
5xx responses are considered to be failures.



### Observability Tools

* [BigQuery: Top http clients by number of requests, cny stage, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:dea839bd669e41b5bc264c510294bb9f)
* [BigQuery: Top http clients by number of requests, main stage, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:704c6bdf00a743d195d344306bf207ee)

panels.content:
### Description

Measures aggregated L4 traffic through the HAProxy. Traffic is measured in TCP connections,
with upstream TCP connection failures being treated as service-level failures.



### Observability Tools

* [BigQuery: Top ssh clients by number of requests, 10m](https://console.cloud.google.com/bigquery?project=gitlab-production&sq=805818759045:8a185b18fafe4081bf9fbdb5354844f9)

panels.content:
### Description

The number of requests meeting their duration target based on the urgency
of the endpoint. By default, a request should take no more than 1s. But
this can be adjusted by endpoint.

Read more about this in the [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/application_slis/rails_request_apdex.html).

panels.title: Details

panels.description: Apdex is a measure of requests that complete within a tolerable period of time for the service. Higher is better.

seriesOverrides.alias: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: workhorse SLI Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_5m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_30m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_6h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: Error rates are a measure of unhandled service exceptions per second. Client errors are excluded when possible. Lower is better

seriesOverrides.alias: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

targets.legendFormat: 6h Degradation SLO (5% of monthly error budget)
1h Outage SLO (2% of monthly error budget)

panels.title: workhorse SLI Error Ratio

targets.expr:
sum (
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_5m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_1h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (14.4 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_30m{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(8) and on() (gitlab_component_errors:ratio_6h{component="workhorse",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} > on(tier, type) group_left() (6 * slo:max:events:gitlab_service_errors:ratio{component="workhorse",monitor="global",type="git"})),
    "period", "6h", "", ""
  )
)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.
panels.title: workhorse SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Monitors the Workhorse instance running in the Git fleet, via the HTTP interface. This SLI
excludes API requests, which have their own SLI with tigher latency thresholds.
Websocket connections are excluded from the apdex score.

panels.title: workhorse_auth_api SLI Apdex

targets.expr:
sum(
  label_replace(
    vector(0) and on() (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse_auth_api",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"}),
    "period", "na", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(1) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_5m{component="workhorse_auth_api",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse_auth_api",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "5m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(2) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_1h{component="workhorse_auth_api",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (14.4 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse_auth_api",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "1h", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(
    vector(4) and on () (gitlab_component_apdex:ratio_30m{component="workhorse_auth_api",env="$environment",environment="$environment",monitor="global",stage="$stage",type="git"} < on(tier, type) group_left() (1 - (6 * (1 - slo:min:events:gitlab_service_apdex:ratio{component="workhorse_auth_api",monitor="global",type="git"})))),
    "period", "30m", "", ""
  )
  or
  label_replace(

)

panels.description: The operation rate is the sum total of all requests being handle for all components within this service. Note that a single user request can lead to requests to multiple components. Higher is busier.
panels.title: workhorse_auth_api SLI RPS - Requests per Second

panels.content:
### Description

Monitors Workhorse API endpoints, running in the Git fleet, via the HTTP interface.
Workhorse API requests have much tigher latency requirements, as these requests originate in GitLab-Shell
and are on the critical path for authentication of Git SSH commands.



### Observability Tools

* [Google Stackdriver Continuous Profiling](https://console.cloud.google.com/profiler;timespan=4h/workhorse-git;type=CPU/cpu?project=gitlab-production)
* [üêû Sentry Releases: gitlab/gitlab-workhorse-gitlabcom](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlab-workhorse-gitlabcom/releases?environment=${environment})
* [üêû Sentry issues](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlab-workhorse-gitlabcom/issues?environment=${environment})

panels.description:
Ratio of requested CPU resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by memory requests already.
panels.title: Node CPU Requests Utilization

panels.description:
Ratio of requested Memory resources from allocatable resources.
Ideally we have requests utilization close to 100%. Values are
below 100% typically because pods do not fit well on nodes or
because we might be bound by CPU requests already.
panels.title: Node Memory Requests Utilization

panels.description:
Kubernetes containers are allocated a share of CPU. When this is exhausted, the container may be thottled.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by (environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        rate(container_cpu_usage_seconds_total:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
        container_spec_cpu_quota:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
        /
        container_spec_cpu_period:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_cpu component saturation: Kube Container CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Records the total memory utilization for containers for this service, as a percentage of
the memory limit as configured through Kubernetes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, pod, container) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      container_memory_working_set_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      /
      (container_spec_memory_limit_bytes:labeled{container!="", container!="POD", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"} > 0)
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_container_memory component saturation: Kube Container Memory Utilization

panels.description:
Measures Go memory usage as a percentage of container memory limit
 Lower is better.
panels.title: kube_go_memory component saturation: Go Memory Utilization per Node

panels.description:
The [Horizontal Pod Autoscaler](https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/run-application/horizontal-pod-autoscale/)
automatically scales the number of Pods in a deployment based on metrics.

The Horizontal Pod Autoscaler has a configured upper maximum. When this
limit is reached, the HPA will not increase the number of pods and other
resource saturation (eg, CPU, memory) may occur.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, horizontalpodautoscaler, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_status_desired_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|imports|memory-bound|urgent-other"}
      /
      kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_spec_max_replicas:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git", shard!~"database-throttled|elasticsearch|gitaly-throttled|imports|memory-bound|urgent-other"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_horizontalpodautoscaler_desired_replicas component saturation: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler Desired Replicas

panels.description:
This resource measures average CPU utilization across an all cores in the node pool for
a service fleet.

If it is becoming saturated, it may indicate that the fleet needs horizontal scaling.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      1 - avg by (environment, tier, type, stage) (
        rate(node_cpu_seconds_total:labeled{mode="idle", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_cpu component saturation: Average Node Pool CPU Utilization

panels.description:
A GKE kubernetes node pool is close to it's maximum number of nodes.

The maximum is defined in terraform, via the `max_node_count` field of a node pool. The limit is per-zone, so for
single zone clusters the number of nodes will match the limit, for regional clusters, the limit is multiplied by
the number of zones the cluster is deployed over.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(env, environment, tier, type, stage, cluster, label_pool, shard) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      count by (cluster, env, environment, label_pool, tier, type, stage, shard) (
        kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      )
      / on(cluster, env, environment, label_pool) group_left() (
        label_replace(
          terraform_report_google_cluster_node_pool_max_node_count,
          "label_pool", "$0", "pool_name", ".*"
        )
        * on(cluster, env, environment) group_left()
        count by (cluster, env, environment) (
          group by (cluster, env, environment, label_topology_kubernetes_io_zone) (
            kube_node_labels:labeled{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
          )
        )
      )
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: kube_pool_max_nodes component saturation: Kube Pool Max Node Limit

panels.description:
Open file descriptor utilization per instance.

Saturation on file descriptor limits may indicate a resource-descriptor leak in the application.

As a temporary fix, you may want to consider restarting the affected process.
 Lower is better.
panels.title: open_fds component saturation: Open file descriptor utilization per instance

panels.description:
Rails uses connection pools for its database connections. As each
node may have multiple connection pools, this is by node and by
database host.

Read more about this resource in our [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/database/client_side_connection_pool.html#client-side-connection-pool).

If this resource is saturated, it may indicate that our connection
pools are not correctly sized, perhaps because an unexpected
application thread is using a database connection.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, instance, host, port) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      (
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_busy{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
        +
        avg_over_time(gitlab_database_connection_pool_dead{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[5m])
      )
      /
      gitlab_database_connection_pool_size{class="ActiveRecord::Base", env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: rails_db_connection_pool component saturation: Rails DB Connection Pool Utilization

panels.description:
Ruby (technically Ruby MRI), like some other scripting languages, uses a Global VM lock (GVL) also known as a
Global Interpreter Lock (GIL) to ensure that multiple threads can execute safely. Ruby code is only allowed to
execute in one thread in a process at a time. When calling out to c extensions, the thread can cede the lock to
other thread while it continues to execute.

This means that when CPU-bound workloads run in a multithreaded environment such as Puma or Sidekiq, contention
with other Ruby worker threads running in the same process can occur, effectively slowing thoses threads down as
they await GVL entry.

Often the best fix for this situation is to add more workers by scaling up the fleet.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    quantile by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn, pod) (
  0.99,
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      rate(ruby_process_cpu_seconds_total{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[10m])
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: ruby_thread_contention component saturation: Ruby Thread Contention

panels.description:
Puma thread utilization per node.

Puma uses a fixed size thread pool to handle HTTP requests. This metric shows how many threads are busy handling requests. When this resource is saturated,
we will see puma queuing taking place. Leading to slowdowns across the application.

Puma saturation is usually caused by latency problems in downstream services: usually Gitaly or Postgres, but possibly also Redis.
Puma saturation can also be caused by traffic spikes.
 Lower is better.

targets.expr:
clamp_min(
  clamp_max(
    max by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (
  clamp_min(
    clamp_max(
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (avg_over_time(instance:puma_active_connections:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"}[1m]))
      /
      sum by(environment, tier, type, stage, fqdn) (instance:puma_max_threads:sum{env="$environment",environment="$environment",stage="$stage",type="git"})
      ,
      1)
  ,
  0)
)

  ,1)
,0)

panels.title: single_node_puma_workers component saturation: Puma Worker Saturation per Node
